questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with a headache which gets worse in the morning, associated with nausea, vomiting, and vertigo. The radiograph revealed a type of brain tumour in the 4th ventricle. Which of the following is the investigation of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MRI

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation suggests Ependymoma, and the investigation of choice for this condition is MRI.
  • Origin: Arises from the cuboidal or columnar epithelium lining the ventricular system in the cerebral hemisphere
  • In children, ependymoma is typically located in the 4th ventricle, whereas in adults, it commonly arises from the filum terminale in the lumbosacral region.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice, and it is treated by resection followed by EBRT (External Radiation Beam Therapy)
  • Ultrasound (Option B), CT scan (Option D), and X-ray (Option C) might help detect it, but cannot be confirmed.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with symptoms of spinal cord compression, including back pain and weakness in the legs. MRI reveals a spinal tumour. Which of the following statements about spinal tumours is NOT true?

choices.text: Osteoblastic metastases are often associated with prostate cancer
Ependymomas are the most common intramedullary tumours in adults
The malignant primary tumour usually involves the vertebral body
Most common Mets to the spine are from the Lungs

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Most common mets to the spine are from Lungs

 

Explanation:

The most common mets to the spine are from Breast malignancies followed by Lung.

 

Spinal Tumors:

  • 20% of the central nervous system (CNS) tumours are spinal tumours & mostly Benign
  • It affects stability and compresses neural structures, leading to pain(typically worse at night), deformities, and functional impairments.

Tumor Category

Type

Description

Extradural Tumors (55%)

Metastatic Tumors

The most common spine tumours, with the most common metastases, are Breast (21%), Lung (14%), Prostate (7.5%), and RCC.

Osteolytic Mets

Lung cancer, RCC, Multiple myeloma.

Osteoblastic Mets

Prostate cancer. (Option A)

Primary Tumors (2%)

Benign

Osteoid osteoma, osteoblastoma, chondroma, chondroblastoma, giant cell tumours, hemangioma, and lymphangioma typically occur in posterior elements.

Intermediate

Aggressive osteoblastoma, chordoma.

Malignant
  • Osteosarcoma, chondrosarcoma, Ewing’s sarcoma, neuroectodermal tumours, lymphoma, fibrosarcoma, and liposarcoma
  • It usually involves the vertebral body. (Option C)

Intradural Tumors (40%)

Extramedullary
  • They arise from the meninges or nerve roots.
  • Examples include meningiomas (dural-based, often in the thoracic spine) and schwannomas (benign, from the nerve sheath).
  • Neurofibromas are fusiform and can grow within nerve roots.

Intramedullary

Arise within spinal cord parenchyma; include ependymomas (most common in adults) (Option B) and astrocytomas (common in children).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of immunosuppression is suspected for Primary CNS lymphoma and evaluated. Which of the following is not accurate about this condition?

choices.text: Often shows a dramatic but short-lived response to steroids.
Steroids should be withheld before biopsy.
Diagnosis is confirmed with a stereotactic biopsy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Shows no response to steroids.

 

Explanation:

  • Primary CNS lymphoma typically shows a dramatic but short-lived response to steroids. (Option A)
  • Steroids have a cytolytic effect on the tumour cells and should be withheld before biopsy to ensure accurate diagnosis. (Option B)
  • Cytolytic effect of steroids causes partial/complete resolution on CT. Hence, it is also called a Ghost cell tumour.

 

Primary CNS lymphoma is a rare but increasingly common tumour of the central nervous system, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as those with AIDS or transplant recipients. Imaging typically shows hyperdense, enhancing lesions.

  • Immunocompetent patients: Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL)
  • Immunocompromised patients: More aggressive large cell variant.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed via stereotactic biopsy. (Option D)
  • Treatment:
    • Chemotherapy (especially high-dose methotrexate) and Radiation therapy (EBRT)
    • AIDS patient - Include highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).
  • Prognosis: Survival is very short (Usually < 1 Year)

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a small brain metastasis is being considered for Stereotactic Radiosurgery (SRS). Which statement correctly describes Stereotactic Radiosurgery (SRS)?

choices.text: Delivers broad radiation to treat the entire brain.
Delivers a focused dose of radiation to the tumour from multiple angles.
Requires prior surgical removal of the tumour.
Used for large, invasive tumours needing extensive surgery.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Delivers a focused dose of radiation to the tumour from multiple angles.

 

Explanation:

  • Stereotactic Radiation Surgery (SRS) delivers a high dose of targeted radiation to a specific brain volume, minimizing damage to surrounding tissue.
  • Non-surgical radiation therapy to treat functional brain abnormalities and small tumours.
  • Techniques:
    • Gamma Knife (Source: Cobalt-60): Focuses radiation from multiple directions on a single point.
    • Modified Linear Accelerator (Source: High-energy X-rays): Delivers radiation in multiple arcs to minimise damage to surrounding tissue.

  • Types:
    • Frameless Systems: These systems utilise advanced imaging, fiducials, and real-time tracking with robotic arms and infrared reflectors. They help plan incisions and combine with intraoperative ultrasound to determine tumour resection.
    • Frame-Based Systems: Involve a rigid frame attached to the skull, used with CT or MRI to determine target coordinates. This method is helpful for brain biopsies, deep brain stimulation, and SRS.
  • Applications: SRS is Commonly used in conditions like
    • Brain tumours
    • Benign lesions of cranial nerves
    • Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs)
    • Trigeminal neuralgia
  • Risks:
    • Radiation necrosis
    • Damage to surrounding brain structures

 

Stereotactic Body Radiotherapy (SBRT): Used for tumours outside the brain, such as in the lung, liver, abdomen, and prostate. It targets medium to small tumours with high precision.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman visits your clinic with complaints of missed periods and noticeable visual disturbances over the past few months. She also reports frequent headaches and mild galactorrhea. MRI shows the findings given in the image. What visual defect is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bitemporal Hemianopia

 

Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario, with Amenorrhea and Galactirhea and an MRI showing mass in the Sella tunica, most probably indicates Pituitary Adenoma (Prolactinoma).
  • The most common visual defect associated with Pituitary Adenoma is Bitemporal hemianopia, which results from the compression of Binasal fibres that cross at the Optic Chiasma.
  • It is the most common Suprasellar mass in adults.
  • Classification:
    • Microadenomas: <10 mm; often incidental or present with endocrine symptoms.
    • Macroadenomas: >10 mm; may cause visual field deficits due to mass effect.
  • Common Types:
    • Prolactinomas: 30% of cases present with amenorrhea and galactorrhea.
    • Non-functioning Adenomas: 20%; no hormone secretion.
    • Growth Hormone-Secreting Adenomas: 15%; causes acromegaly.
    • ACTH-Secreting Adenomas: 10% leads to Cushing's disease.
  • Clinical features:
    • Visual Defect: Compression of the optic chiasm often causes bitemporal hemianopia.
    • Endocrine Symptoms: Amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and other hormonal imbalances.
  • Imaging and diagnosis involve MRI as the primary modality, along with serum prolactin and thyroid function tests and visual field charting.
  • Treatment:
    • Medical management
      • Prolactinomas: Dopamine agonists (e.g., bromocriptine, cabergoline).
      • Growth Hormone-Secreting Tumors: Somatostatin analogues (e.g., octreotide).
  • Surgical managemnt
    • Transsphenoidal Approach: Preferred for most cases; craniotomy may be needed for large tumours.
    • Sublabial Approach
    • Indications: Acute visual deterioration, GH-secreting tumours, Cushing's disease, or large non-functioning adenomas causing symptoms.

 

  • Complications:
    • Pituitary Apoplexy: Sudden haemorrhage or infarction in the tumour, presenting with headache, visual loss, and ophthalmoplegia.
    • Postoperative Risks: CSF leaks, pituitary insufficiency, and diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with headache, vomiting, blurring of vision, weakness, recent aggression, and weight gain. Examination reveals growth retardation and signs of hypopituitarism. MRI findings are noted. Which of the following is not true regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is more common in children
It is derived from pituitary stalk

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is derived from the pituitary stalk

 

Explanation:

  • The given features suggest Craniopharyngioma, derived from Rathke’s pouch near the pituitary stalk and extends into the suprasellar cistern.
  • It is histologically a benign tumour but may sometimes have local aggressive and relentless behaviour.
  • It is more commonly seen in children, with the peak incidence between 5 and 10 years of age (Option B).
  • Clinically, it presents with headache, vomiting, papilledema, hydrocephalus, visual field, abnormality, cranial nerve palsies, sleep difficulty, weight gain, personality changes, etc.
  • Its characteristic features are:
    • Hypopituitarism (Option A)
    • Growth retardation (Option D)
    • Diabetes insipidus
  • Investigations used are MRI and CT.
  • Management is by surgical resection followed by post-op radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient presents with complaints of difficulty understanding speech and tinnitus. On examination, there is unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, reduced corneal sensitivity, and numbness of the face. Which of the following nerves is most commonly involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Inferior vestibular nerve

 

Explanation:

  • The given scenario suggests a case of Acoustic neuroma (also known as vestibular schwannoma, neurilemmoma, or eight-nerve tumour), which most commonly involves the inferior vestibular nerve.
  • It is a benign, encapsulated, extremely slow-growing tumour of the VIII cranial nerve.
  • It consists of spindle cells with rod-shaped nuclei lying in rows.
  • It is classified as,
    • Intracanalicular (confined to the internal auditory canal)
    • Small size (<1.5cm)
    • Medium size (1.5 - 4 cm)
    • Large size (>4cm)
  • The tumour most commonly emerges from the inferior vestibular nerve (Option A) and compresses the superior vestibular nerve (Option B), cochlear nerve (Option C) and facial nerve (Option D).
  • Clinical features:
    • Commonly seen in the age group of 40-60 years.
    • Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss
    • Tinnitus
    • Difficulty in understanding speech,
    • Reduced corneal sensitivity
    • Numbness or paresthesia
    • Speech and swallowing problems are seen
    • Ataxia
  • The investigation of choice is MRI with contrast, which shows the appearance of an ice cream cone. BERA is also used to investigate audiological issues.

 

  • Management includes surgical excision (if the size is more than 3cm) and radiosurgery (for tumours less than 30cc)

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presented with headache, blurring of vision, weakness and loss of balance. His radiological investigations suggested hydrocephalus and pheochromocytoma. A tumour is detected whose radiograph is given below. Which of the following genetic syndromes is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) VHL syndrome

 

Explanation:

The above features suggest Hemangioblastoma and the associated genetic disorder is VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) syndrome.

 

Hemangioblastoma is a benign vascular tumour of the central nervous system associated with VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) syndrome, which consists of the following,

  • Cerebellar hemangioblastoma.
  • Retinal hemangioma
  • RCC(Renal Cell Carcinoma)
  • Renal cyst
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Epididymal/ broad ligament cyst adenoma
  • Endolymphatic sac tumours
  • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors

 

MRI in hemangioblastoma shows a cystic tumour with a non-enhancing wall and enhancing mural nodule, which is managed by surgical resection.

MEN I Syndrome (OptionA), also known as Wermer syndrome, is associated with endocrine tumours, such as pituitary, parathyroid, and pancreatic.

 

Lynch syndrome (Option C) is an autosomal dominant condition characterised by multiple adenomatous polyps. It has two types: Lynch I and Lynch II.

 

Gardner’s syndrome (Option D) is an autosomal dominant condition and is associated with FAP (familial adenomatous polyposis). It is also associated with other conditions like osteoma, desmoid tumours, sebaceous cysts, etc.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with complaints of severe morning headache associated with nausea, vomiting and seizure. On examination, the doctor suspected a brain tumour and suggested an MRI, which revealed a tumour at the vermis region. Which of the following syndromes is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Turcot’s syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • The above features suggest Medulloblastoma, the most common type of primitive neuroectodermal tumour (PNET) and the most common malignant pediatric brain tumour.
  • It predominantly occurs in the first decade of life, with a second peak around age 30.
  • Histology: Characterized by densely packed small round cells with large nuclei and scant cytoplasm.
  • Location: Typically found in the cerebellum (vermis) in children and the lateral cerebellar hemisphere in adults.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms include headache, vomiting, nausea, weakness, papilledema, and ataxia.
  • Diagnosis: MRI is used for imaging.
  • Management: Treatment involves surgical resection followed by radiotherapy and chemotherapy.
  • Association: Medulloblastoma is associated with Turcot's syndrome.


 

Gorlin syndrome (Option A), also known as Basal cell naevus syndrome, is associated with basal cell carcinomas, medulloblastoma, and bifid ribs.

 

NF1 (Neurofibromatosis-1) syndrome (Option B) is associated with astrocytomas, primitive neuroectodermal tumours, optic gliomas, and multiple neurofibromas.

 

VHL (Von Hippel-Lindau) syndrome (Option C) VHL syndrome is associated with hemangioblastoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with worsening headaches, cognitive issues, and personality changes. MRI reveals a large mass in the left frontal lobe with surrounding oedema, likely a primary brain tumour. What is the overall most common type of primary brain tumour in adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Meningioma

 

Explanation:

  • Meningiomas are the most common primary brain tumours in adults.
  • They are typically benign and arise from the meninges, the layers of tissue covering the brain and spinal cord.
  • They account for about 36-37% of all primary brain tumours in adults, making them the most frequent type.
  • Depending on their location, meningiomas can cause symptoms such as headaches, seizures, and neurological deficits, including cognitive and personality changes when located in the frontal lobe.
  • The slow-growing nature of these tumours often leads to gradual symptom progression.


 

Medulloblastomas (Option A) are highly malignant tumours originating from the cerebellum and are most commonly seen in children. They typically cause cerebellar dysfunction, such as ataxia, and increased intracranial pressure, leading to headaches and vomiting. These tumours are rare in adults, especially in the frontal lobe.

 

Glioblastomas (GBMs) (Option B) are aggressive, malignant tumours arising from astrocytes and are the most common malignant primary brain tumour in adults. They present rapidly with symptoms like headaches, seizures, cognitive decline, and focal neurological deficits. However, they are less common than meningiomas.

 

Oligodendrogliomas (Option D) originate from oligodendrocytes, which produce the myelin sheath in the central nervous system. These tumours often present with seizures and may occur in the frontal lobe. They are less common than meningiomas, slower-growing than glioblastomas, and have a better prognosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent seizures and headaches. MRI reveals a mass located in the cerebral hemisphere. Histopathological examination of the mass shows cells with a "fried egg" appearance and a chicken-wire capillary pattern. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Oligodendroglioma

Explanation: The given clinical presentation and histopathological features suggest Oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendroglioma:

Aspect

Description

Definition
  • Primary brain tumours arise from oligodendrocytes (glial cells supporting neurons).
  • It is often slow-growing and typically occurs in adults aged 40-50.

Clinical Features
  • Seizures
  • Headaches
  • Focal neurological deficits

Histopathological (HPE) Findings
  • "Fried-egg" appearance of tumour cells
  • Chicken-wire capillary pattern

Radiological Findings
  • MRI is preferred for diagnosis.
  • Contrast-enhancing mass in the cerebral hemispheres
  • It may show calcifications and oedema

Treatment
  • Surgery: Aim to remove as much of the tumour as possible while preserving brain tissue.
  • 5-ALA fluorescence-guided surgery: Helps visualise tumour cells for more accurate resection.
  • Chemotherapy: Temozolomide is commonly used.
  • Radiation Therapy: Recommended for high-grade tumors or when complete removal is not feasible.

 

 

Meningioma (Option A) is usually an extra-axial tumour with a dural attachment; the tumour shows calcifications and cells arranged in whorls.

 

Craniopharyngioma (Option C) typically presents in the suprasellar region and has distinct cystic and calcified components.

 

Glioblastoma (Option D) is a high-grade tumour characterised by pleomorphic cells, necrosis, and vascular proliferation, not the features described here.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with headaches and visual disturbances. Imaging studies reveal a well-circumscribed mass in the brain. On histopathological examination, the tumour shows calcifications and cells arranged in whorls. Which of the following radiological findings is most characteristic of this tumour type?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Dural tail sign

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with headaches and visual disturbances, and imaging studies reveal a well-circumscribed brain mass and histopathological examination showing calcifications and cells arranged in whorls strongly suggests a diagnosis of meningioma.
  • The dural tail sign is the most characteristic imaging feature associated with meningiomas.

Meningioma:

Aspect

Description

Definition

Benign tumours arise from the meninges surrounding the brain and spinal cord.

Clinical Features
  • Headaches
  • Visual disturbances
  • Neurological deficits due to mass effect
  • Vasogenic oedema (brain swelling)
  • Potential for obstructive hydrocephalus (if CSF flow is blocked)

Radiological Features
  • Contrast-enhancing mass
  • Dural base attachment
  • Possible calcifications
  • Dural tail sign (specific to meningiomas)

Management
  • Surgery (preferred if the tumour is large or symptomatic)
  • Radiotherapy or stereotactic radiosurgery if surgery is risky.
  • Watch-and-wait approach for small, incidental tumours in older patients.

 

Calcified mass (Option A): Calcifications are usually seen in meningiomas but are not as specific as the dural tail sign.

 

Ring enhancement (Option B) pattern is more commonly associated with abscesses or glioblastomas and is not characteristic of meningiomas.

 

Vasogenic oedema (Option D): Meningiomas can cause vasogenic oedema due to the mass effect on surrounding brain tissue. However, this finding is non-specific and can be seen with various other brain tumours.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with worsening headaches, focal neurological deficits, and personality changes. MRI imaging reveals a ring-enhancing lesion surrounded by significant oedema. Based on these imaging characteristics, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and management in recurrent cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Glioblastoma Multiforme, Temozolomide

Explanation:

  • The imaging findings of a ring-enhancing lesion with significant surrounding oedema are characteristic of Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM), AKA Grade 4 Astrocytoma.
  • It is a Grade IV glioma characterised by ring-enhancing lesions on MRI with surrounding oedema and is associated with poor prognosis.
  • It is highly aggressive and presents with necrosis and microvascular proliferation.
  • Temozolomide is the current chemotherapy drug of choice for GBM.

 

In the MRI image, look for:

  • Ring-enhancing lesions: GBM typically shows a ring-like enhancement pattern due to its necrotic core and surrounding inflammation.
  • Significant surrounding oedema: Common in GBM due to its aggressive infiltration and impact on adjacent brain tissue.

Meningioma (Option A) typically presents as well-defined, extra-axial lesions and is usually found on the brain's surface. They often show a homogenous enhancement on MRI and are less likely to be ring-enhancing lesions surrounded by oedema.

 

Metastatic Brain Tumor (Option C) presents as ring-enhancing lesions but is usually multiple and located in different brain regions. They are often associated with a known primary cancer elsewhere in the body.

 

Primary CNS Lymphoma (Option D) appears as a solitary lesion but typically shows less ring enhancement and less surrounding oedema compared to GBM. It usually occurs in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with headaches and focal neurological deficits. Imaging reveals a tumour located in the cerebral hemispheres, characterised by infiltrative growth and low cellularity. Which of the following options best describes the likely diagnosis for this tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Diffuse Astrocytoma

Explanation: The diffuse astrocytoma fits the clinical description of infiltrative growth and low cellularity and is commonly located in the cerebral hemispheres.

Diffuse Astrocytoma

  • Prognosis: Intermediate
  • Common Site: Cerebral hemispheres
  • Histological Features: Infiltrative, low cellularity. These tumours are characterised by their gradual growth and infiltration into surrounding brain tissue.
  • Management: Surgical resection is the primary treatment. Radiation or chemotherapy might be considered based on risk factors or residual disease.

 

WHO Classification of Astrocytomas:

WHO Grade

Tumor Type

Prognosis

Common Site

Histological Features

Management

Grade I

Pilocytic Astrocytoma

Good

Posterior fossa (children)

Well-circumscribed, low mitotic index

Surgical resection; observation or adjuvant therapy

Grade II

Diffuse Astrocytoma

Intermediate

Cerebral hemispheres

Infiltrative, low cellularity

Surgical resection; may consider radiation or chemotherapy

Grade III

Anaplastic Astrocytoma

Poor

Cerebral hemispheres

High cellularity, mitotic activity

Surgical resection followed by radiation and chemotherapy

Grade IV

Glioblastoma Multiforme

Very Poor

Frontal/temporal lobes

Necrosis, microvascular proliferation

Surgical resection, followed by radiation and temozolomide chemotherapy

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presents with headaches, vomiting, and unsteady gait. Imaging reveals a mass in the posterior fossa. The lesion is surgically resected, and histology reveals a tumour with a low mitotic index. Which of the following best describes the most common location and prognosis of this tumour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cerebellum, Good prognosis

Explanation:

The given scenario with mass in the posterior fossa is highly suggestive of a tumour in the cerebellum, particularly a pilocytic astrocytoma, which has a good prognosis.

  • It is a low-grade (WHO Grade I), slow-growing, often benign brain tumour primarily affecting children and young adults.
  • They usually arise in the cerebellum but can also be found in the optic pathways, brainstem, and spinal cord.
  • Histologically, it is characterised by
    • Biphasic pattern with dense fibrillary areas and loose microcystic regions.
    • Rosenthal fibres (eosinophilic, corkscrew-shaped fibres) are often present.
  • On MRI, it appears as a well-circumscribed cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule.
  • Surgical resection is the primary treatment and can be curative due to the tumour's well-defined borders.
  • Excellent prognosis, with long-term survival rates exceeding 90% following complete resection. If fully removed, recurrence is rare.

 

 

 

 

Histopathology of Pilocytic astrocytoma

questions.text: Which type of brain tumour is most likely to cause personality changes, impaired judgment, and difficulty with motor planning?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Frontal lobe tumors

 

Explanation:

Frontal lobe tumours are most likely to cause personality changes, impaired judgment, and difficulty with motor planning.

 

Functions of the frontal lobe:

  • Executive Functions: The frontal lobe is essential for reasoning, planning, and decision-making, and tumours can impair these abilities, affecting judgment.
  • Personality and Social Behavior: Tumours can lead to significant personality changes and inappropriate behaviour.
  • Motor Planning and Control: The primary motor cortex in the frontal lobe controls voluntary movements, and tumours can disrupt motor planning and execution, leading to difficulties with complex movements.

Temporal lobe tumours (Option B) typically cause memory problems (particularly difficulty forming new memories), auditory hallucinations, language comprehension difficulties, and seizures.

Occipital lobe tumours (Option C) mainly affect vision and visual processing, causing symptoms such as visual hallucinations, difficulty recognising objects or faces, and partial or complete loss of vision.

Cerebellar tumours (Option D) typically cause problems with balance and coordination, difficulty with fine motor skills, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), and slurred speech.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with worsening headaches, confusion, ataxia, and right-sided weakness. A CT scan reveals multiple ring-enhancing brain lesions and further imaging identifies a mass in the right upper lobe of the lung. What is the most likely primary source of brain metastases?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lung cancer

 

Explanation:

  • Lung cancer is the most common cause of brain metastases, accounting for 40-50% of all cases.
  • It is the leading cause of brain metastases, particularly in patients with a history of smoking by hematogenous spread.
  • Symptoms include worsening headaches, confusion, and balance issues, which are consistent with brain metastases.
  • The presence of multiple ring-enhancing brain lesions is typical of metastatic brain disease.

 

Colorectal cancer (Option A): Less commonly metastasises to the brain, typically affecting the liver, lungs, and bones.

Prostate cancer (Option B): Rarely spreads to the brain, with metastases usually found in bones, lymph nodes, and the liver.

Melanoma (Option D) has a high propensity for brain metastasis but is less common overall than lung cancer. It typically metastasises to lymph nodes and the liver.
